description: From un- +‎ thought. Compare Old English unþanc (“disfavour, displeasure, anger, ill-will”).

examples: For Bion it is not thinking which produces thoughts but unthought thoughts which require an apparatus for thinking them.

entries.meaning: That which has not been (yet) thought; that which has yet to enter into the mind; a non-existent thought.
examples: But without his knowing, they interfere with his research and at the very least call on him to put the results in perspective. This is what we call the “unthoughts” of scientific work.

entries.meaning: simple past tense and past participle of unthink
